justification: The article introduces “the drift-diffusion model (DDM)” as “the mathematical framework that describes the optimal solution to two-alternative forced choice on the basis of unreliable evidence,” indicating that evidence accumulation is operationalised with the DDM.

Referring to Murty et al. (2016), the authors note that participants preferred lotteries "only for lotteries whose values were correctly identified in a subsequent recognition memory test," showing that a Recognition Memory Test was used to measure episodic memory accuracy.

measured_by: Recognition Memory Probes in the Ticket Bandit Task
justification: In the ‘ticket’ bandit paradigm, “choice trials were interspersed with recognition memory probes that implicitly reminded participants of selected past choices,” and the ensuing choice bias was modelled as a memory-sampling effect, indicating the probes serve as the measurement tool for memory-based choice bias.

The review states that “neural decision variables measured in fMRI were better explained by a memory sampling model than by TDRL,” specifying fMRI as the instrument used to measure neural decision variables while participants decided.
